message.raw:
Added a threading.Event to delay the return of results to lyse if the user requests it.

This allows the user to use the Plot subclass to interact with the data, and save additional results to HDF5 file via custom actions on their toolbar (which could be the result of user interaction with the plot) and then return the results to lyse (for example either on a button click, or after a timeout, or whatever you like!)

To use, call `lyse.delay_results_return()` at the end of your script.
Results will then only be returned to lyse (so lyse will be stuck waiting for your analysis script to complete) until `lyse.delay_event.set()` is called (through some event ultimately processed by the Qt event loop).

To use, call lyse.delay_results_return() at the end of your script.
Results will then only be returned to lyse (so lyse will be stuck waiting for your analysis script to complete) until lyse.delay_event.set() is called (through some event ultimately processed by the Qt event loop).

message.raw:
Added the ability for analysis scripts to register a custom Plot class

This allows you to provide custom behaviour in plot windows (such as additional actions)

Use `lyse.register_plot_class(identifier, cls)` to register a class for lyse to use when creating window for `figure(identifier)`, where cls must be a subclass of `lyse.Plot` (which is monkey patched in to the lyse module to avoid the double import denier script triggering if you try to import it directly from lyse.analysis_subprocess)

Currently we do not support changing the class from one run of the script to the next, without restarting the worker process (as that would require re-instantiating the plot which has a large number of problems). Also, in order to avoid the custom subclass being detected as changing from shot to shot, it needs to be imported from a separate module to the analysis script. If an invalid class is specified, then the default `Plot` class is used and message is printed in the lyse terminal.

I also changed the indexing of the internal storage of plots to use the identifier rather than the fig object. This seems to make much more sense to me, and since we also now expose that dictionary to the analysis script via `lyse.plots`, I figured now would be a good time to change it! I can't see any downside to doing this but please correct me if I'm wrong.

Finally, this obviously has no effect on lyse scripts run from the terminal, since we don't use our figure manager in such cases. A warning is printed informing the user in such instances (if they use `lyse.register_plot_class()`)

message.raw:
Performance optimisation.

* lookup rows in dataframe by filepath using a dictionary cache rather
  than searching the dataframe. This removes the need for the method
  get_model_row_by_filepath(), so it has been removed and the dictionary used
  directly.

* Remove redundant getting of the row index again for the Qt model - it is
  the same row as the dataframe

* Avoid setting the text of a QStandardItem twice by only creating it once
  the text it should have is known

* Add an argument to renumber_rows() that allows it to only renumber recent
  rows for the case that new rows have been added and don't have numbers yet
  but the existing row numbers are still valid

* Modify batch processing of shot files to use a dynamic batch size, with
  larger batches the more shots lyse has loaded. This is a good tradeoff
  between GUI responsiveness when there are a small number of shot files
  and speed when loading a large number of shot files. The batch size is 1/3
  of the number of shots. Larger batch sizes mean less redundant concatenation
  of dataframes.

* Modify the progress bar message to say when it's reading shot files
  vs concatenating dataframes vs updating the filebox GUI.

message.raw:
Removed debugging printlines.

Reverted to use exec(code, snadbox) directly instead of six.exec_, since the
tuple form of the exec statement is valid Python 2 that is forward compatible
with exec being a function in Python 3.

Modified the traceback logic to not hit on a CPython bug in CPython < 2.7.9
that made Python throw an error about the exec.

message.raw:
Fixed bug: when adding to sys.path a bytestring should be added, not
a unicode string.

This allows relative paths to be used for exec() later since the paths
are relative to entries in sys.path, and the traceback code will
look in sys.path for the file. Previously we got an error when linecache
was trying to join entries in sys.path with the filename, but now
both are bytestrings so it should all be good.

In Python 3 of course they will need to be unicode strings. Each encode/decode
line will need to become conditional on Python version.

message.raw:
Unicode dataframe column labels, and all `__future__` imports enabled.

execfile() replaced with compile & exec, as forward compatible with Python 3
(as well as allowing for non-ascii filenames, addressing issue #28).

Require zprocess 2.2.2 which fixes a bug that prevented sending non-ascii
characters to the output box.

`str` aliased to `unicode` in Python 2.

These changes are not tested in Python 3, but getting all strings unicode in
Python 2 as well as all other __future__ imports enabled is a good first step
for Python 3 compatibility.

In Python 2, unicode strings and bytestrings pass equality checks, meaning that
indexing dataframes with bytestrings will still get the right columns even
though the column labels are now unicode strings:

```
>>> df[u'test_ümlaut', 'x']
sequence                   run time
2017-06-21 13:17:38-04:00  2017-07-25 16:15:53-04:00    70.0
                           2017-07-25 16:15:54-04:00    70.0
                           2017-07-25 16:15:54-04:00    70.0
                           2017-07-25 16:15:54-04:00    70.0
                           2017-07-25 16:15:54-04:00    70.0
Name: (test_ümlaut, x), dtype: float64
```

message.raw:
Support integer indexing of the lyse DataFrame, using a MultiIndex of:
['sequence_index', 'run number', 'run repeat']

This can be enabled in labconfig using:
   [lyse]
   integer_indexing = true

If this section or option are absent from the labconfig file, fallback to the
existing indexing by ['sequence', 'run time'].

This feature supports much easier use of pd.DataFrame.loc, e.g.
   df = lyse.data()
   df.loc[56]       # sequence 56 MultiIndexed by ['run number', 'repeat number']
   df.loc[56:60]    # sequences 56 through 60 inclusive
   df.loc[56,4]     # run number 4 of sequence 56, indexed by 'repeat number'
   df.loc[56,2:6,:] # runs 2 through 6 (inclusive) of sequence 56

Enabling this feature changes the vertical header item to read, e.g.
   105. 0056 | 0001 | 0106

This is far more useful, as these integers can all be used to construct a .loc
or .iloc call to the lyse DataFrame.

The main problem with this feature is that the MultiIndex might not be unique if
new shots are sent to or loaded into lyse with an existing sequence_index, e.g.
if the sequence_index gets reset in runmanager or shots are loaded from multiple
days.

The main problem with this feature is that the MultiIndex might not be unique if
new shots are sent to or loaded into lyse with an existing sequence_index, e.g.
if the sequence_index gets reset in runmanager or shots are loaded from multiple
days.
summary.html:
Support integer indexing of the lyse DataFrame, using a MultiIndex of:
['sequence_index', 'run number', 'run repeat']

This can be enabled in labconfig using:
[lyse]
integer_indexing = true

If this section or option are absent from the labconfig file, fallback to the
existing indexing by ['sequence', 'run time'].

This feature supports much easier use of pd.DataFrame.loc, e.g.
df = lyse.data()
df.loc[56] # sequence 56 MultiIndexed by ['run number', 'repeat number']
df.loc[56:60] # sequences 56 through 60 inclusive
df.loc[56,4] # run number 4 of sequence 56, indexed by 'repeat number'
df.loc[56,2:6,:] # runs 2 through 6 (inclusive) of sequence 56

Enabling this feature changes the vertical header item to read, e.g.
105. 0056 | 0001 | 0106

This is far more useful, as these integers can all be used to construct a .loc
or .iloc call to the lyse DataFrame.

The main problem with this feature is that the MultiIndex might not be unique if
new shots are sent to or loaded into lyse with an existing sequence_index, e.g.
if the sequence_index gets reset in runmanager or shots are loaded from multiple
days.

message.raw:
Fix a bug in updating the dataframe after analysis has produced results.
Pandas would raise an exception if you tried to save an iterable item
as a value in the dataframe, because of ambiguities as to whether you are
trying to set multiple values or not.

Since we are only setting one value at a time, I've changed the form
of the call to pandas to one that is explicitly for setting single
values, removing the ambiguity and allowing iterable values to be set.

message.raw:
Fix bug where restoring the window position/size when a different number
of monotors or different monitor resolution is in use compared to when that
information was saved could potentially move the window off the screen.

Made it so that if the number of screens and their sizes is not the same
as when the data was saved, to simply fall back on defaults.

This way those with a consistent setup will get lyse in the same position
they left it, and those with a varying setup will get the defaults after
their setup changes.
